scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of your team members, Lisa, says: 'I don't think we can meet this deadline. It's just too much work in too little time.' You responded by acknowledging the difficulty and suggesting to prioritize tasks and see if additional resources are needed. As the team begins to break down the tasks, [Monica] seems hesitant and [Bob] looks frustrated. You advised the team to stay focused on what they can control. [Monica] and [Bob] still seem uneasy.
scenes.description: [Monica] frowns and says: 'I get it, but it still feels like we're fighting a losing battle here.' [Bob] nods in agreement and adds with a sarcastic tone: 'Yeah, let's just keep doing our best while the ship sinks.'

options.text: I get that it feels overwhelming. Let's take a short break and then tackle it one step at a time.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the team's feelings and suggested a constructive way to manage the workload, showing good emotional detection and interpersonal balance skills.

options.text: I hear you. Maybe it's time to reassess our priorities and see what can be postponed.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the team's concerns and suggested a practical solution, showing good emotional control and social skills, though emotional perception could be slightly improved.

options.text: I think we're all frustrated, but complaining won't help. Let's focus on what needs to be done.
options.analysis: You emphasized the importance of focusing on tasks, showing good communication skills, but emotional perception and interpersonal balance could be improved.
